Text: A Psalm. A Song for the dedication of the temple. By David.
Context: This introduction identifies the Psalm as a song written by David for the dedication of the temple, setting a ceremonial context for the Psalm.

Text: I will exalt You, LORD, for You have lifted me up and have not let my enemies gloat over me.
Context: David expresses praise and thanks to God for deliverance from a situation where his enemies could have rejoiced over his downfall.

Text: LORD my God, I called to You for help, and You healed me.
Context: Continuing his thanks, David affirms God's response to prayer, specifically regarding healing, suggesting physical or emotional distress.

Text: O LORD, You have brought me up from Sheol; You spared me from descending into the Pit.
Context: David describes being rescued from a near-death experience or a state of hopelessness, referring to Sheol, the abode of the dead.

Text: Sing to the LORD, O you His saints, and praise His holy name.
Context: David calls on the faithful community to join in worship and praise, emphasizing the holiness of God.

Text: For His anger lasts only a moment, but His favor, a lifetime. Weeping may stay the night, but joy comes in the morning.
Context: Expressing God's nature, this verse contrasts temporary sorrow with the enduring joy that God provides, affirming divine mercy.

Text: When I felt secure, I said, “I will never be shaken.”
Context: David recalls a time of confidence when he felt firmly established, unthreatened by any instability.

Text: LORD, by Your favor You made my mountain stand strong; when You hid Your face, I was dismayed.
Context: Reflecting on God's blessings which give stability, David also acknowledges his dependence on God's presence, expressing distress when God seems distant.

Text: To You, O LORD, I called; to the Lord I pleaded for mercy:
Context: David recounts reaching out to the Lord in a time of need, seeking God's mercy, implying a situation of distress or desperation.

Text: “What gain is there in my destruction, in my going down to the Pit? Will the dust praise You? Will it proclaim Your truth?
Context: David presents a rhetorical question, arguing the value of his life in terms of continued praise and proclamation of God's truth, as opposed to death.

Text: Hear, O LORD, and be merciful to me; LORD, be my helper.
Context: David appeals for God's mercy and assistance in a humble, petitioning tone.

Text: You turned my mourning into dancing; You peeled off my sackcloth and clothed me with joy,
Context: David celebrates the transformation from sorrow to joy through God's intervention, metaphorically describing the change from mourning garments to those of celebration.

Text: That my heart may sing Your praises and not be silent. O LORD my God, I will give thanks forever.
Context: David expresses a vow to continually praise and thank God, emphasizing the enduring commitment to worship as a response to God's deliverance.
